case_name: Widow of Kanji Jadhavji v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: The appellant is the widow of Kanji Jadhavji.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave. The appellant is the widow of one Kanji Jadhavji. Kanji Jadhavji had extensive business such as stevedoring, companyl hauling, freight brokerage, clearing and forwarding of goods, loading and unloading of steamers, chartering of steamers, etc.

facts.text: Kanji Jadhavji had extensive business such as stevedoring, companyl hauling, freight brokerage, clearing and forwarding of goods, loading and unloading of steamers, chartering of steamers, etc.

anchor.surface_text: Kanji Jadhavji had extensive business such as stevedoring, companyl hauling, freight brokerage, clearing and forwarding of goods, loading and unloading of steamers, chartering of steamers, etc. These business the widow inherited on the death of her husband.

facts.text: The widow inherited the businesses on the death of her husband.

anchor.surface_text: These business the widow inherited on the death of her husband. For the assessment year 1947-48, the relevant accounting year being the calendar year 1946, the appellant was assessed on a total Income of Rs. 3,69,371 which was subsequently reduced to Rs. 2,99,471 by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1947-48, relevant accounting year calendar year 1946, appellant assessed on total income Rs. 3,69,371 reduced to Rs. 2,99,471 by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1947-48, the relevant accounting year being the calendar year 1946, the appellant was assessed on a total Income of Rs. 3,69,371 which was subsequently reduced to Rs. 2,99,471 by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer added Rs. 1,38,000 as income from undisclosed source from high denomination notes encashed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: While assessing the appellant, the Income-tax Officer companycerned added a sum of Rs. 1,38,000 being the amount of certain high denomination numberes encashed by the appellant, as income from undisclosed source.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner against the addition.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by this addition, the appellant appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: No books of account available for 1944-45 and first four months of 1945-46 due to destruction from explosion in Bombay docks on April 14, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: No books of account were, however, available for the year 1944-1945 and for the first four months of 1945-1946, some of these books, it was stated, were destroyed as a result of an explosion which took place in the Bombay docks on April 14, 1944.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner successor dismissed the appeal holding ITO justified in adding Rs. 1,38,000.

anchor.surface_text: By the time the appeal was heard the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who had called for the aforesaid statement was transferred. His successor-in-office who dealt with the appeal held that the Income-tax Officer was justified in adding Rs. 1,38,000 as income from undisclosed sources.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by order dated May 6, 1959 dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Then, there was an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay. By its order dated May 6, 1959, the Appellate Tribunal held that there was numberpositive and tangible proof...

facts.text: Appellant encashed 246 high denomination currency notes total value Rs. 2,46,000 when High Denomination Notes Demonetisation Ordinance promulgated in January 1946.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated here that the appellant had encashed 246 high denomination currency numberes of the total value of Rs. 2,46,000 at the time when the High denomination Notes  Demonetisation  Ordinance was promulgated in January, 1946.

facts.text: Appellant declared sources of high denomination notes: 1. movable and immovable properties including cash left by husband, 2. profits from inherited business, 3. rents and income from landed properties, 4. moneys withdrawn from business, 5. three fixed deposits withdrawn in 1942 due to WWII panic.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the appellant made a declaration to the effect that the sources from which she had companye into possession of the high denomination numberes were  1  movable and immovable properties including cash left by her husband,  2  the profits which she was made from the business of her husband inherited by her,  3  rents and income from her landed propertied,  4  the moneys she had withdrawn from the said business from time to time and  5  three fixed deposits which the appellant had in three banks, these deposits having been withdrawn in 1942 when there was a panic arising out of the Second World War.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held eight notes part of day-to-day cash balance of business.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the aforesaid 246 numberes the Income-tax Officer held that eight numberes formed part of day-to-day cash balance of the business of the appellant.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held Rs. 1,00,000 at most representing savings, remaining Rs. 1,38,000 income from undisclosed sources from 238 notes.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the remaining 238 numberes, the Income-tax Officer held that a sum of Rs. 1,00,000 companyld at most be treated as representing the saving of the appellant from all source therefore, he held that the remaining sum of Rs. 1,38,000 was the appellants income from undisclosed sources.

facts.text: Appellant moved Tribunal for reference to High Court under section 66(1) Income-tax Act 1922, rejected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the Tribunal for referring certain questions of law which according to her arose out of the Tribunals order dated May 6, 1959, to the High Court under section 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922. ... The Tribunal rejected the application...

facts.text: High Court dismissed application under section 66(2) on March 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the High Court under section 66 2  of the Act for an order directing the Tribunal to state a case... This application was summarily dismissed by the High Court on March 27, 1961.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal from High Court order dated March 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved this companyrt for special leave to appeal from the order of the High Court dated March 27, 1961. This companyrt granted special leave and the present appeal has been preferred...

facts.text: Her husband died in 1931, under his will she had to disburse legacies worth Rs. 2,50,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal said Her husband died in 1931, and, under his will, she had admittedly to disburse legacies worth Rs. 2,50,000.

facts.text: Appellant had fixed deposit accounts worth Rs. 4,98,041 swelled to Rs. 5,40,774 by 1940-41, withdrew Rs. 4,00,220 in early 1942 due to war panic.

anchor.surface_text: Besides property investments over five lakhs in the late thirties, she had three fixed deposit accounts in three banks worth Rs. 4,98,041. These fixed deposit amounts swelled by 1940-41 to Rs. 5,40,774 out of which, during the war panic she withdrew Rs. 4,00,220 in early 1942...

facts.text: Withdrawn fixed deposits reinvested: Rs. 2,53,980 in municipal bonds September 1942, Rs. 70,000 shares 1943, further in municipal debentures 1945.

anchor.surface_text: but these moneys withdrawn were reinvested in September, 1942, and 1943. These investments companyprised Rs. 2,53,980 in September, 1942, in the municipal bonds and Rs. 70,000 in 1943, in shares, followed by a further investment in 1945, in the municipal debentures.

facts.text: After encashment, Rs. 2,14,000 reinvested in municipal debentures, Rs. 24,000 in Scindia shares.

anchor.surface_text: Soon after the encashment of these numberes Rs. 2,14,000 were reinvested in municipal debentures and Rs. 24,000 in Scindia shares.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside High Court order dated March 27, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we allow this appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated March 27, 1961, by which it summarily rejected the application for a reference under section 66 of the Act.

facts.text: In Bai Velbai Kanji account cash withdrawals 1934-1945 nearly two lakhs utilised towards legacies.

anchor.surface_text: In the former account the cash withdrawals from 1934 to 1945 came to hardly less than two lakhs and on her own showing, this companyld have been utilised largely towards the payment of legacies.

facts.text: Capital accounts statements prepared for 1936-37 to 1946-47 showing withdrawals.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer also prepared statements of the capital accounts in the different books of the appellant and the amounts withdrawn by her therefrom, for the assessment years 1936-1937 to 1946-1947.
This is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the aforesaid 246 notes the Income-tax Officer held that eight notes formed part of day-to-day cash balance of the business of the appellant. As regards the remaining 238 notes, the Income-tax Officer held that a sum of Rs. 1,00,000 could at most be treated as representing the saving of the appellant from all source therefore, he held that the remaining sum of Rs. 1,38,000 was the appellants income from undisclosed sources.

arguments.claim: Appellant had sources for high denomination notes: movable/immovable properties/cash from husband, profits from inherited business, rents/income from properties, withdrawals from business, fixed deposits withdrawn in 1942 due to war panic

anchor.surface_text: At that time the appellant made a declaration to the effect that the sources from which she had come into possession of the high denomination notes were 1 movable and immovable properties including cash left by her husband, 2 the profits which she made from the business of her husband inherited by her, 3 rents and income from her landed properties, 4 the moneys she had withdrawn from the said business from time to time and 5 three fixed deposits which the appellant had in three banks, these deposits having been withdrawn in 1942 when there was a panic arising out of the Second World War.

arguments.claim: The appellant is the type of shrewd lady making judicious investments who would not keep huge amount like Rs. 2,50,000 in loose idle cash; withdrawals from fixed deposits reinvested; legacies disbursements used withdrawals; no plausible source for cash

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal said Her husband died in 1931, and, under his will, she had admittedly to disburse legacies worth Rs. 2,50,000. ... It is, therefore, obvious that she is a shrewd lady making judicious investments from year to year. It is impossible to believe that she could have kept this huge amount of about Rs. 2,50,000 in loose and idle cash or notes in her safe as an utterly unremunerative capital.

arguments.claim: A finding of fact is open to attack under section 66 as erroneous in law when there is no evidence to support it or if it is perverse or reached without due consideration of relevant facts

anchor.surface_text: As this court observed in Sree Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, a finding of fact does not alter its character as one of fact merely because it is itself an inference from other basic facts but a finding on a question of fact is open to attack under section 66 as erroneous in law when there is no evidence to support it or if it is perverse or has been reached without due consideration of the several relevant for such a determination.

arguments.claim: The present case falls under the category where Tribunal's finding is based on no evidence, conjecture, surmise, and failure to consider crucial matters like cash withdrawals from capital accounts totaling enough to explain the cash

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has argued that the present case comes under the second category aforesaid and the High Court was wrong in summarily rejecting the application for a reference. ... If these withdrawals are added to what the appellant had withdrawn from her fixed deposit amounts in the three banks, learned counsel for the appellant contends that the total amount would come to about Rs. 6,00,000 and would satisfactorily account for the large amount of cash in her hands.

arguments.claim: Tribunal gave no reasons for distinguishing Rs.1,00,000 savings from Rs.1,38,000 undisclosed; ITO also no particular materials; failed to consider appellant's explanation for remaining funds after reinvestments; ignored business cash withdrawals 1939-1946

anchor.surface_text: We may first point out that the Tribunal has given no reasons of its own for making a distinction between the sum of Rs. 1,00,000 and the sum of Rs. 1,38,000 ... The Tribunal did indeed refer to the withdrawals ... What, however, the Tribunal failed to consider was the withdrawals which the appellant had made in cash from the capital accounts in her different business from 1936-1937 to 1945-1946.

arguments.claim: Tribunal's finding that legacies disbursements spread over long period is surmise without evidence; even after withdrawals for legacies, large sum left

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal pointed out that the appellant had to disburse legacies worth Rs. 2,50,000 under the will left by her husband. The Tribunal opined that these disbursement must have been spread over quite a long period. The complaint of learned counsel for the appellant is that there is no evidence that the disbursements were spread over a long period and the finding of the Tribunal was based on a mere surmise.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ore, is vitiated by a failure to take into companysideration several crucial matters bearing on the question. We may first point out that the Tribunal

arguments.claim: Income-tax Officer's calculation of withdrawals inconsistent: first excluded household etc., later said portion went to legacies etc., based on surmise

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellant has also made a grievance of the fact that in calculating the withdrawals made by the appellant from her businesses, the Income-tax Officer had first excluded withdrawals on account of household expenses, income-tax, etc but later on he said that a portion of the cash withdrawals together with the income from properties and the cash left by the appellants husband must have gone to pay the legacies, household expenses, etc. This again is said to be based on surmise rather than on any evidence on record.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient for us to say at this stage that the three questions which the appellant has raised and to which we have made a reference earlier in this judgment are questions of law which do arise out of the Tribunals order dated May 6, 1959.

arguments.claim: In considering probabilities from proved facts, Tribunal must not indulge in conjectures, surmises or suspicions

anchor.surface_text: We have read the order of the Tribunal as a whole and we are not unmindful of the observation made in the case of Homi Jehangir Gheesta that in considering probabilities properly arising from the facts alleged or proved, the Tribunal does not indulge in conjectures, surmises or suspicions.

holdings.text: the three questions which the appellant has raised and to which we have made a reference earlier in this judgment are questions of law which do arise out of the Tribunals order dated May 6, 1959

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient for us to say at this stage that the three questions which the appellant has raised and to which we have made a reference earlier in this judgment are questions of law which do arise out of the Tribunals order dated May 6, 1959. In coming to this conclusion we have kept in mind the observations made by this court in Omar Salary Mahomed Sait v. Commissioner of Income-tax, and Homi Jehangir Gheesta v. Commissioner of Income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court reviews Tribunal order prima facie for lack of evidence, conjecture, surmise, failure to consider cash withdrawals from capital accounts and fixed deposits, applies Sree Meenakshi Mills test distinguishing pure fact from reviewable legal errors

holdings.text: a finding on a question of fact is open to attack under section 66 as erroneous in law when there is no evidence to support it or if it is perverse or has been reached without due consideration of the several relevant facts for such a determination

anchor.surface_text: As this court observed in Sree Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, a finding of fact does not alter its character as one of fact merely because it is itself an inference from other basic facts but a finding on a question of fact is open to attack under section 66 as erroneous in law when there is no evidence to support it or if it is perverse or has been reached without due consideration of the several relevant for such a determination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts and applies Supreme Court precedent in Sree Meenakshi Mills to categorize Tribunal's undisclosed income finding as potentially erroneous in law due to evidentiary defects

holdings.text: the High Court was wrong in summarily rejecting the application for a reference

anchor.surface_text: We may perhaps add that what we have said in this judgment is meant only to show that certain questions of law arise out of the Tribunals order and the High Court was wrong in summarily rejecting the application for a reference. As to how the questions of law should be answered will be a matter for the High Court to decide when on the statement of the case filed by the Tribunal the reference is dealt with by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred by not recognizing arguable questions of law on perversity and evidentiary failures in Tribunal's fact-finding under s.66 IT Act

holdings.text: we allow this appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated March 27, 1961, by which it summarily rejected the application for a reference under section 66 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above we allow this appeal and set aside the order of the High Court dated March 27, 1961, by which it summarily rejected the application for a reference under section 66 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural relief granted as questions of law arise warranting Tribunal reference to High Court per s.66 IT Act

holdings.text: learned counsel for the appellant has prima facie given good grounds for his contention that the finding of the Tribunal as to the sum of Rs. 1,38,000 is based on no evidence rather it is based on conjecture and surmise, and, furthermore, is vitiated by a failure to take into consideration several crucial matters bearing on the question

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that learned counsel for the appellant has prima facie given good grounds for his contention that the finding of the Tribunal as to the sum of Rs. 1,38,000 is based on no evidence rather it is based on conjecture and surmise, and, furthermore, is vitiated by a failure to take into consideration several crucial matters bearing on the question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prima facie assessment of Tribunal errors in ignoring business cash withdrawals, arbitrary distinction between allowed and added amounts, surmise on legacy disbursements

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient for us to say at this stage that the three questions which the appellant has raised and to which we have made a reference earlier in this judgment are questions of law which do arise out of the Tribunals order dated May 6, 1959. In coming to this conclusion we have kept in mind the observations made by this court in Omar Salary Mahomed Sait v. Commissioner of Income-tax, and Homi Jehangir Gheesta v. Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: We may perhaps add that what we have said in this judgment is meant only to show that certain questions of law arise out of the Tribunals order and the High Court was wrong in summarily rejecting the application for a reference. As to how the questions of law should be answered will be a matter for the High Court to decide when on the statement of the case filed by the Tribunal the reference is dealt with by it.
